The Inferior leads consist of which lead: The Lateral leads consist of which leads?
Leads I, AvL, V5, and V6.

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: The Anterior leads consist of which leads?
The Septal leads consist of which leads?
ST-segment elevation of at least 2mm in any anatomically contiguous leads suggests what?
ST-segment depression or 'T' wave inversion may be indicative of what?
Which leads are known as the precordial or chest leads?
V1, V2, V3, V4, V5, and V6.

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: Reciprocal ST-segment changes can be noted where?
In the leads away from the infarct.

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: To perform a rapid Right sided 12-Lead, what precordial lead must be moved to the same location on the Right side?
When moved to the opposite side V4 now becomes V4R, and a rapid Right sided 12-Lead ECG may be performed.

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: For a bundle branch block (BBB) to be present, the QRS duration must be greater than what?
Any QRS duration greater than 120mm constitutes a BBB.

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: What type of medical condition should be suspected if you notice ST-segment elevation in all leads?
A normal axis?
A physiologic Left axis deviation?
A pathological Left axis deviation?
A Right axis deviation?
An extreme Right axis deviation?
True or False?  A 12-Lead ECG can be performed by only using a 3-Lead monitor?
True, by moving the LL(red) lead to all the V-Lead (precordial) positions and switching to Lead III, you can capture the same views of the myocardium as a 12-Lead ECG!

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: Which leads are known as the axial or limb leads?
LA(black), LL(red), RA(white), and RL(green).
Salt(RA), pepper(LA), ketchup(LL), and relish(RL).

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: The heart consists of these coronary vessels?
The RCA(right coronary artery) and the LCA(left coronary artery), which then branches into the LAD(left anterior descending artery) and the LCX(left circumflex).

The Inferior leads consist of which lead: If axis deviates away from the injured myocardium, then a lateral infarct would most likely yield a what type axis deviation?
A pathological 'Q' wave, must be greater than 25% of overall QRS depth, is usually indicative of what?
